switch dont  needs ip address for communication but needs mac address. but if destination mac address is unknown then for arp protocol, ip address is required.
coz switches  have the abality to store the MAC address so through  MAC address the data will be send to destination and MAC adress works in layer 2 in OSI model so thats why it works on layer 2

ARP broadcast is sent by source/originating host/PC to learn the MAC address of a destination host/PC. The switch sends the ARP broadcast out every live/connected port except the incoming port the message was received on. The host/PC with the matching IP address in the ARP request will respond to the request with a Unicast message to the sending host, giving its own MAC address. When the switch receives this Unicast message on the incoming port, the switch then populates both its ARP cache and MAC Address Table with this information.

Yes I do face the same issue

One word: ARP! If there has been no network traffic on the network so far (or it has cleared) the switch tables will not be populated with the MAC address to Port relationship. Also, the ARP table on the PC/host will only contain its own MAC Address to IP address relationship. Sending a ping (or other packet) from one host to another would populate the MAC/ARP tables for these devices.  However, when you send a ping for the first time, the host PC knows the IP of the receiving device (because this is what you are pinging) but it does not yet know the MAC address of the other PC to send the packet to, so it sends an ARP request (broadcast to ffff.ffff.ffff) which the switch then sends out of every port except the incoming port the ARP packet was received on.  The ARP request is “saying”: Hello, my MAC is aaaa.aaaa.aaaa (IP 10.10.10.1), is there a computer on the same network with an IP address of 10.10.10.4? If so, please tell me your MAC address! This is what you are seeing. The switch forwards the ARP broadcast out of every other port, “looking” for any device on the network with the correct IP address to respond with its MAC address.
